content: Try controlled breathing exercises . Get into a comfortable position, then breathe in deeply through your nose and fill your belly with air. Count slowly to five as you breathe in, then gently exhale through your mouth as you count to five again. [2] Do your breathing exercises for three to five minutes whenever you feel overwhelmed or experience other symptoms. Instead of counting as you breathe, you can also think or say a soothing word, like "relax." [3] Meditate for 20 to 30 minutes a day. Wear loose, comfortable clothes, and set aside some time when you’ll be free of distractions. Sit upright with your chest out and shoulders back. Keep your feet flat on the floor if you’re sitting in a chair, or cross your legs if you’re on the floor. Close your eyes, breathe deeply, and envision your breath flowing in and out of you. [4] Focus completely on your breath as you inhale through your nose and exhale through your mouth. Imagine each breath fills you with light, and draws wandering, chaotic thoughts to a single point. If you notice your attention wandering from your breath, just refocus again. Don’t judge or criticize yourself, simply return your attention to your breath. You can also look for guided meditations on YouTube and other services. Practice positive self talk. When a negative thought comes to mind, acknowledge it instead of trying to push it aside. Say it out loud or write it down, then say, “This is a negative, exaggerated thought.” Challenge it with a realistic thought to take away its power. [5] For example, if you starting thinking to yourself, “I’m worthless,” acknowledge the thought and say, “No - that’s an exaggerated, black and white thought. My family needs me, my friends treasure me, and my boss values my work.” Do your best to take the power away from negative thoughts before they start to spiral. Try not to see things as black and white or absolute and unchangeable. Celebrate every small success. Throughout the day, stop to acknowledge small victories. Depression can make it tough just to get out of bed, so even something seemingly minor like getting dressed could be something to celebrate. [6] Try starting your day by making the bed. It might seem trivial, but it’s a way to start off each day with an accomplishment. Praise yourself for things like cleaning, going outside, cooking a healthy meal, and exercising. Visualize calming situations. Sit somewhere comfortable without distractions, close your eyes, and breathe slowly. Calm your mind by focusing on peaceful images. Think of a place that you find relaxing, like a childhood refuge, a mountain retreat, or an exotic beach location. [7] Open your imagination to the sensations that you would feel in this place: the sounds, smells, colors, textures, and temperature. Visualize the place with as many sensory details as you can. Spend 10 to 15 minutes in this restful place before opening your eyes. Visualization can help you relax, minimize stress, and improve the quality of your sleep. Visualize solutions to your conflict. You can also visualize positive resolutions if a specific conflict prompted your symptoms. Identify your conflict and bring its image to mind. If you stand before it and feel very small, inhale deeply, and imagine yourself growing taller and taller. Imagine that from this new height you have the power to see new ways to solve the problem. [8] For example, if you’re feeling powerless, overwhelmed, and hopeless because of a fight with your significant other, envision yourself becoming larger than the conflict. Say to yourself, “I have the power to resolve this conflict.” Then, try to break down the situation into its facts, and visualize a conversation with your partner that could resolve the conflict. Listen to calming music. Listening to music can ease stress, depression, and anxiety. Play your favorite soothing tracks when you’re at home, going for a walk, or driving your car. Instead of watching television, try turning on the stereo. [9] The type of music that relaxes you will depend on your personal preference. Singing can also be a great way to relax or release tension. Stretch your muscles to raise your spirits. Take 10 to 15 minutes to stretch when you wake up and before you go to bed. Develop a routine and stretch your legs , back , and arms. Stretching regularly can energize your body, increase blood flow to your muscles, and help relieve symptoms of anxiety and depression. [10] Since it might be hard to get motivated enough to exercise, stretching can be a good way to get moving if you’re depressed. Try progressive muscle relaxation . Set aside about 15 minutes of time free of distractions. Find a comfortable place to sit, close your eyes, and take several slow, deep breaths. Inhale and tense one muscle group, such as your toes, then hold the tension for about five seconds. [11] Let the tension go and relax the muscles as you exhale slowly. Notice the muscles go limp as the tension disappears. Repeat the process and work through the muscles in your legs, torso, arms, shoulders, neck, and head.   Try to get daily aerobic exercise. From walking the dog to taking judo classes, aerobic exercise isn’t just good for your heart. It can reduce stress hormones and stimulate mood-elevating chemicals in your brain. Focusing on movement while you exercise also allows you to take a break from depression and any conflicts surrounding it. [12] Having an exercise buddy can help keep you accountable on those days when you just want to stay in bed. Try to enlist a friend to help! Start doing yoga . Yoga involves meditation, physical exercise, and controlled breathing, so it can help ease both your mind and body. If you’re a beginner , look for classes at your local YMCA or yoga studio. You can also search for yoga videos on YouTube and health and fitness websites. [13] Try to get seven to nine hours of sleep each night. Depression and difficulty sleeping often go hand in hand. [14] If you have trouble getting the recommended amount of sleep, try to work on developing healthy sleeping habits: [15] Go to bed and wake up at the same time each day. Expose yourself to bright light just after waking. Avoid eating a heavy meal within two or three hours of bedtime. Avoid caffeine and alcohol, especially in the evening. Eat a balanced diet. Foods that contain lots of sugar, fat, and salt can mess with your brain’s reward system, which can worsen depression. Do your best to limit foods that can worsen depression , and maintain a healthy, balanced diet. [16] Make sure you eat the recommended daily servings of proteins, fruits and veggies, and grains. You can find your daily requirements, recipe suggestions, and other nutrition resources on MyPlate: /tn/myplate . Avoid consuming alcohol, caffeine, and other drugs. Like junk food, alcohol, caffeine, nicotine, and other drugs can mess up your reward system and worsen depression. [17]  Do your best to reduce your consumption of any of these substances. If possible, try to quit. Drugs and alcohol can also interact with prescription medications. It’s important to be honest with your doctor and discuss potential drug interactions with them. Do something you enjoy every day. Allowing yourself to experience a simple pleasure is a key part of self care. Make a mental list of things you love to do and schedule time every day for your me-time. [18] Examples might include enjoying a good cup of coffee on the patio, getting a massage, taking a hot bath, painting or drawing, and snuggling up with a blanket and good book. Don’t overbook yourself. When you make too many commitments, you set yourself up to fail. Stress can lead to feeling overwhelmed and depressed, so try to avoid packing your schedule. Break big projects up into smaller tasks that you can complete over several days, and don’t be afraid to say no to commitments you can’t keep. [19] Avoid procrastinating so things don’t pile up on you. Remember to give yourself time for breaks. Never feel bad if you need time to restore and recharge. Try keeping a journal . Journaling can help you release tension, put order to chaotic feelings, track your progress over time, and find motivation to handle future struggles. Set aside 15 or 20 minutes to jot down that day’s events, your feelings, conflicts, and worries. Every two or three weeks, read back your entries to remind yourself how you’ve overcome problems. [20] Do your best to stay social. Depression often leads to isolation, which in turn feeds depression and creates a vicious cycle. When you feel like isolating yourself, do your best to motivate yourself to reach out to someone. Give a friend or family member a call and ask them if they can hang out or have a chat. [21] Other ways to stay social might be a local support group, religious services, or a group hobby or exercise class.

<div class="section sticky hasad" id="intro">
<h1 class="firstHeading no_toc"><a href="https://www.wikihow.com/Ease-Depression-with-Relaxation-Techniques">How to Ease Depression with Relaxation Techniques</a></h1>
<div class="ss_check" id="expert_coauthor">
	
	Co-authored by <a class="expert_icon expert_coauthor_link" href="#article_info_section">
		Tasha Rube, LMSW</a>
</div>

<div id="sp_icon_body">
		This article was co-authored by <a href="/Special:ArticleReviewers?name=tasharube%2Clmsw#tasharube%2Clmsw">Tasha Rube, LMSW</a>. Tasha Rube is a Licensed Master Social Worker in Missouri. She received her MSW from the University of Missouri in 2014.<br/><br/>There are <a href="#references">21 references</a> cited in this article, which can be found at the bottom of the page.
		
	</div>
</div>
<p>Living with depression can be an immense struggle. If you’re feeling overwhelmed, anxious, or hopeless, relaxation techniques could help you find some relief.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 1" class="reference" id="_ref-1"><a href="#_note-1">[1]</a></sup> Try doing breathing exercises, meditation, and positive thinking practices. Physical activities, like stretching, yoga, and aerobic exercise, can also help ease symptoms of depression. Remember that self-care is key to reducing stress and coping with depression. Eat a healthy diet, do your best to get enough sleep, and do something daily that nourishes your mind and body.</p>

<h2 class="hidden"><span class="mw-headline" id="Steps">Steps</span></h2>
<a class="anchor" name="Calming_Your_Mind_sub"></a><div class="section steps sticky steps_first">
<h3>
<div class="altblock"><label class="method_label">Method</label> <span>1</span>
</div>
<span class="mw-headline" id="Calming_Your_Mind">Calming Your Mind</span>
</h3>
<div class="section_text" id="steps_1">
<ol class="steps_list_2">
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Ease-Depression-with-Relaxation-Techniques-Step-1-Version-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=53961" href="#/Image:Ease-Depression-with-Relaxation-Techniques-Step-1-Version-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Ease Depression with Relaxation Techniques Step 1" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c7/Ease-Depression-with-Relaxation-Techniques-Step-1-Version-2.jpg/aid53961-v4-728px-Ease-Depression-with-Relaxation-Techniques-Step-1-Version-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_1bf9e639df" onload="WH.performance.clearMarks('image1_rendered'); WH.performance.mark('image1_rendered');" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_1bf9e639df')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Ease Depression with Relaxation Techniques Step 1" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" onload="WH.performance.clearMarks('image1_rendered'); WH.performance.mark('image1_rendered');" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c7/Ease-Depression-with-Relaxation-Techniques-Step-1-Version-2.jpg/aid53961-v4-728px-Ease-Depression-with-Relaxation-Techniques-Step-1-Version-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript>
<script>WH.performance.clearMarks('image1_rendered'); WH.performance.mark('image1_rendered');</script></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 1" class="step_num">1</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_1"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Try <a href="/Do-Breathing-Exercises" title="Do Breathing Exercises">controlled breathing exercises</a>.</b> Get into a comfortable position, then breathe in deeply through your nose and fill your belly with air. Count slowly to five as you breathe in, then gently exhale through your mouth as you count to five again. <sup aria-label="Link to Reference 2" class="reference" id="_ref-2"><a href="#_note-2">[2]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>Do your breathing exercises for three to five minutes whenever you feel overwhelmed or experience other symptoms.</li>
<li>Instead of counting as you breathe, you can also think or say a soothing word, like "relax."<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 3" class="reference" id="_ref-3"><a href="#_note-3">[3]</a></sup>
</li>
</ul>
<script>WH.performance.mark('step1_rendered');</script>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Ease-Depression-with-Relaxation-Techniques-Step-2-Version-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=53961" href="#/Image:Ease-Depression-with-Relaxation-Techniques-Step-2-Version-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Ease Depression with Relaxation Techniques Step 2" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/19/Ease-Depression-with-Relaxation-Techniques-Step-2-Version-2.jpg/aid53961-v4-728px-Ease-Depression-with-Relaxation-Techniques-Step-2-Version-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_c3b703475b" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_c3b703475b')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Ease Depression with Relaxation Techniques Step 2" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/19/Ease-Depression-with-Relaxation-Techniques-Step-2-Version-2.jpg/aid53961-v4-728px-Ease-Depression-with-Relaxation-Techniques-Step-2-Version-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 2" class="step_num">2</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_2"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb"><a href="/Treat-Depression-With-Meditation" title="Treat Depression With Meditation">Meditate</a> for 20 to 30 minutes a day.</b> Wear loose, comfortable clothes, and set aside some time when you’ll be free of distractions. Sit upright with your chest out and shoulders back. Keep your feet flat on the floor if you’re sitting in a chair, or cross your legs if you’re on the floor. Close your eyes, breathe deeply, and envision your breath flowing in and out of you.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 4" class="reference" id="_ref-4"><a href="#_note-4">[4]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>Focus completely on your breath as you inhale through your nose and exhale through your mouth. Imagine each breath fills you with light, and draws wandering, chaotic thoughts to a single point.</li>
<li>If you notice your attention wandering from your breath, just refocus again. Don’t judge or criticize yourself, simply return your attention to your breath.</li>
<li>You can also look for guided meditations on YouTube and other services.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Ease-Depression-with-Relaxation-Techniques-Step-3-Version-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=53961" href="#/Image:Ease-Depression-with-Relaxation-Techniques-Step-3-Version-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Ease Depression with Relaxation Techniques Step 3" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/26/Ease-Depression-with-Relaxation-Techniques-Step-3-Version-2.jpg/aid53961-v4-728px-Ease-Depression-with-Relaxation-Techniques-Step-3-Version-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_513b254adc" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_513b254adc')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Ease Depression with Relaxation Techniques Step 3" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/26/Ease-Depression-with-Relaxation-Techniques-Step-3-Version-2.jpg/aid53961-v4-728px-Ease-Depression-with-Relaxation-Techniques-Step-3-Version-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 3" class="step_num">3</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_3"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Practice positive self talk.</b> When a negative thought comes to mind, acknowledge it instead of trying to push it aside. Say it out loud or write it down, then say, “This is a negative, exaggerated thought.” Challenge it with a realistic thought to take away its power.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 5" class="reference" id="_ref-5"><a href="#_note-5">[5]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>For example, if you starting thinking to yourself, “I’m worthless,” acknowledge the thought and say, “No - that’s an exaggerated, black and white thought. My family needs me, my friends treasure me, and my boss values my work.”</li>
<li>Do your best to take the power away from negative thoughts before they start to spiral. Try not to see things as black and white or absolute and unchangeable.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Ease-Depression-with-Relaxation-Techniques-Step-4-Version-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=53961" href="#/Image:Ease-Depression-with-Relaxation-Techniques-Step-4-Version-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Ease Depression with Relaxation Techniques Step 4" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/43/Ease-Depression-with-Relaxation-Techniques-Step-4-Version-2.jpg/aid53961-v4-728px-Ease-Depression-with-Relaxation-Techniques-Step-4-Version-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_f19084d93a" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_f19084d93a')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Ease Depression with Relaxation Techniques Step 4" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/43/Ease-Depression-with-Relaxation-Techniques-Step-4-Version-2.jpg/aid53961-v4-728px-Ease-Depression-with-Relaxation-Techniques-Step-4-Version-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 4" class="step_num">4</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_4"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Celebrate every small success.</b> Throughout the day, stop to acknowledge small victories. Depression can make it tough just to get out of bed, so even something seemingly minor like getting dressed could be something to celebrate.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 6" class="reference" id="_ref-6"><a href="#_note-6">[6]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>Try starting your day by making the bed. It might seem trivial, but it’s a way to start off each day with an accomplishment.</li>
<li>Praise yourself for things like cleaning, going outside, cooking a healthy meal, and exercising.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Ease-Depression-with-Relaxation-Techniques-Step-5-Version-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=53961" href="#/Image:Ease-Depression-with-Relaxation-Techniques-Step-5-Version-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Ease Depression with Relaxation Techniques Step 5" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/1d/Ease-Depression-with-Relaxation-Techniques-Step-5-Version-2.jpg/aid53961-v4-728px-Ease-Depression-with-Relaxation-Techniques-Step-5-Version-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_c672a1cbcf" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_c672a1cbcf')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Ease Depression with Relaxation Techniques Step 5" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/1d/Ease-Depression-with-Relaxation-Techniques-Step-5-Version-2.jpg/aid53961-v4-728px-Ease-Depression-with-Relaxation-Techniques-Step-5-Version-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 5" class="step_num">5</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_5"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Visualize calming situations.</b> Sit somewhere comfortable without distractions, close your eyes, and breathe slowly. Calm your mind by focusing on peaceful images. Think of a place that you find relaxing, like a childhood refuge, a mountain retreat, or an exotic beach location.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 7" class="reference" id="_ref-7"><a href="#_note-7">[7]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>Open your imagination to the sensations that you would feel in this place: the sounds, smells, colors, textures, and temperature. Visualize the place with as many sensory details as you can. Spend 10 to 15 minutes in this restful place before opening your eyes.</li>
<li>Visualization can help you relax, minimize stress, and improve the quality of your sleep.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Ease-Depression-with-Relaxation-Techniques-Step-6-Version-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=53961" href="#/Image:Ease-Depression-with-Relaxation-Techniques-Step-6-Version-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Ease Depression with Relaxation Techniques Step 6" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f6/Ease-Depression-with-Relaxation-Techniques-Step-6-Version-2.jpg/aid53961-v4-728px-Ease-Depression-with-Relaxation-Techniques-Step-6-Version-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_056c143f57" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_056c143f57')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Ease Depression with Relaxation Techniques Step 6" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f6/Ease-Depression-with-Relaxation-Techniques-Step-6-Version-2.jpg/aid53961-v4-728px-Ease-Depression-with-Relaxation-Techniques-Step-6-Version-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 6" class="step_num">6</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_6"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Visualize solutions to your conflict.</b> You can also visualize positive resolutions if a specific conflict prompted your symptoms. Identify your conflict and bring its image to mind. If you stand before it and feel very small, inhale deeply, and imagine yourself growing taller and taller. Imagine that from this new height you have the power to see new ways to solve the problem.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 8" class="reference" id="_ref-8"><a href="#_note-8">[8]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>For example, if you’re feeling powerless, overwhelmed, and hopeless because of a fight with your significant other, envision yourself becoming larger than the conflict. Say to yourself, “I have the power to resolve this conflict.” Then, try to break down the situation into its facts, and visualize a conversation with your partner that could resolve the conflict.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Ease-Depression-with-Relaxation-Techniques-Step-7.jpg?ajax=true&aid=53961" href="#/Image:Ease-Depression-with-Relaxation-Techniques-Step-7.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Ease Depression with Relaxation Techniques Step 7" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/8a/Ease-Depression-with-Relaxation-Techniques-Step-7.jpg/aid53961-v4-728px-Ease-Depression-with-Relaxation-Techniques-Step-7.jpg" height="546" id="img_d4830fe8ef" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_d4830fe8ef')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Ease Depression with Relaxation Techniques Step 7" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/8a/Ease-Depression-with-Relaxation-Techniques-Step-7.jpg/aid53961-v4-728px-Ease-Depression-with-Relaxation-Techniques-Step-7.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 7" class="step_num">7</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_7"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Listen to calming music.</b> Listening to music can ease stress, depression, and anxiety. Play your favorite soothing tracks when you’re at home, going for a walk, or driving your car. Instead of watching television, try turning on the stereo.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 9" class="reference" id="_ref-9"><a href="#_note-9">[9]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>The type of music that relaxes you will depend on your personal preference.</li>
<li>Singing can also be a great way to relax or release tension.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
<div class="wh_ad_inner step_ad" data-adsenseheight="90" data-adsensewidth="728" data-adtargetid="methodad" data-adunitpath="" data-aps-timeout="2000" data-apsload="1" data-channels="6381149051,3492389196" data-lateload="0" data-loaded="0" data-service="dfp" data-slot="" data-viewablerefresh="1">
<div id="methodad"></div>
<script>googletag.cmd.push(function() { googletag.display('methodad'); });</script>
</div>
<div class="clearall adclear"></div>
<script>WH.desktopAds.addBodyAd('methodad')</script>
</li>
</ol>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</div>
</div>
<a class="anchor" name="Trying_Physical_Techniques_sub"></a><div class="section steps sticky">
<h3>
<div class="altblock"><label class="method_label">Method</label> <span>2</span>
</div>
<span class="mw-headline" id="Trying_Physical_Techniques">Trying Physical Techniques</span>
</h3>
<div class="section_text" id="steps_2">
<ol class="steps_list_2">
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Ease-Depression-with-Relaxation-Techniques-Step-8.jpg?ajax=true&aid=53961" href="#/Image:Ease-Depression-with-Relaxation-Techniques-Step-8.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Ease Depression with Relaxation Techniques Step 8" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/95/Ease-Depression-with-Relaxation-Techniques-Step-8.jpg/aid53961-v4-728px-Ease-Depression-with-Relaxation-Techniques-Step-8.jpg" height="546" id="img_5ddeca18ce" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_5ddeca18ce')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Ease Depression with Relaxation Techniques Step 8" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/95/Ease-Depression-with-Relaxation-Techniques-Step-8.jpg/aid53961-v4-728px-Ease-Depression-with-Relaxation-Techniques-Step-8.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 1" class="step_num">1</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_1"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb"><a href="/Stretch" title="Stretch">Stretch your muscles</a> to raise your spirits.</b> Take 10 to 15 minutes to stretch when you wake up and before you go to bed. Develop a routine and stretch your <a href="/Stretch-Your-Legs" title="Stretch Your Legs">legs</a>, <a href="/Stretch-Your-Back" title="Stretch Your Back">back</a>, and arms. Stretching regularly can energize your body, increase blood flow to your muscles, and help relieve symptoms of anxiety and depression.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 10" class="reference" id="_ref-10"><a href="#_note-10">[10]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>Since it might be hard to get motivated enough to exercise, stretching can be a good way to get moving if you’re depressed.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Ease-Depression-with-Relaxation-Techniques-Step-9.jpg?ajax=true&aid=53961" href="#/Image:Ease-Depression-with-Relaxation-Techniques-Step-9.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Ease Depression with Relaxation Techniques Step 9" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/82/Ease-Depression-with-Relaxation-Techniques-Step-9.jpg/aid53961-v4-728px-Ease-Depression-with-Relaxation-Techniques-Step-9.jpg" height="546" id="img_3b0aed59c0" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_3b0aed59c0')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Ease Depression with Relaxation Techniques Step 9" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/82/Ease-Depression-with-Relaxation-Techniques-Step-9.jpg/aid53961-v4-728px-Ease-Depression-with-Relaxation-Techniques-Step-9.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 2" class="step_num">2</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_2"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Try <a href="/Perform-Progressive-Muscle-Relaxation" title="Perform Progressive Muscle Relaxation">progressive muscle relaxation</a>.</b> Set aside about 15 minutes of time free of distractions. Find a comfortable place to sit, close your eyes, and take several slow, deep breaths. Inhale and tense one muscle group, such as your toes, then hold the tension for about five seconds.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 11" class="reference" id="_ref-11"><a href="#_note-11">[11]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>Let the tension go and relax the muscles as you exhale slowly. Notice the muscles go limp as the tension disappears. Repeat the process and work through the muscles in your legs, torso, arms, shoulders, neck, and head.  </li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Ease-Depression-with-Relaxation-Techniques-Step-10.jpg?ajax=true&aid=53961" href="#/Image:Ease-Depression-with-Relaxation-Techniques-Step-10.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Ease Depression with Relaxation Techniques Step 10" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/ed/Ease-Depression-with-Relaxation-Techniques-Step-10.jpg/aid53961-v4-728px-Ease-Depression-with-Relaxation-Techniques-Step-10.jpg" height="546" id="img_e7798c515f" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_e7798c515f')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Ease Depression with Relaxation Techniques Step 10" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/ed/Ease-Depression-with-Relaxation-Techniques-Step-10.jpg/aid53961-v4-728px-Ease-Depression-with-Relaxation-Techniques-Step-10.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 3" class="step_num">3</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_3"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Try to get daily aerobic exercise.</b> From walking the dog to taking <a href="/Do-Judo" title="Do Judo">judo</a> classes, aerobic exercise isn’t just good for your heart. It can reduce stress hormones and stimulate mood-elevating chemicals in your brain. Focusing on movement while you exercise also allows you to take a break from depression and any conflicts surrounding it.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 12" class="reference" id="_ref-12"><a href="#_note-12">[12]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>Having an exercise buddy can help keep you accountable on those days when you just want to stay in bed. Try to enlist a friend to help!</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Ease-Depression-with-Relaxation-Techniques-Step-11.jpg?ajax=true&aid=53961" href="#/Image:Ease-Depression-with-Relaxation-Techniques-Step-11.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Ease Depression with Relaxation Techniques Step 11" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/bc/Ease-Depression-with-Relaxation-Techniques-Step-11.jpg/aid53961-v4-728px-Ease-Depression-with-Relaxation-Techniques-Step-11.jpg" height="546" id="img_6e8dd48ed2" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_6e8dd48ed2')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Ease Depression with Relaxation Techniques Step 11" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/bc/Ease-Depression-with-Relaxation-Techniques-Step-11.jpg/aid53961-v4-728px-Ease-Depression-with-Relaxation-Techniques-Step-11.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 4" class="step_num">4</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_4"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Start <a href="/Do-Yoga" title="Do Yoga">doing yoga</a>.</b> Yoga involves meditation, physical exercise, and controlled breathing, so it can help ease both your mind and body. If you’re a <a href="/Do-Yoga-for-Absolute-Beginners" title="Do Yoga for Absolute Beginners">beginner</a>, look for classes at your local YMCA or yoga studio. You can also search for yoga videos on YouTube and health and fitness websites.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 13" class="reference" id="_ref-13"><a href="#_note-13">[13]</a></sup>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
<div id="tocad_wrap">
<div class="wh_ad_inner step_ad" data-adsenseheight="90" data-adsensewidth="728" data-adtargetid="tocad" data-adunitpath="" data-aps-timeout="2000" data-channels="6381149051,3492389196" data-lateload="1" data-loaded="0" data-service="adsense" data-slot="3356467874" data-viewablerefresh="1" id="tocad_outer"><div class="step_ad" id="tocad"></div></div>
<div class="clearall adclear"></div>
<script>WH.desktopAds.addTOCAd('tocad')</script>
</div>
</li>
</ol>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</div>
</div>
<a class="anchor" name="Taking_Care_of_Yourself_sub"></a><div class="section steps sticky">
<h3>
<div class="altblock"><label class="method_label">Method</label> <span>3</span>
</div>
<span class="mw-headline" id="Taking_Care_of_Yourself">Taking Care of Yourself</span>
</h3>
<div class="section_text" id="steps_3">
<ol class="steps_list_2">
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Ease-Depression-with-Relaxation-Techniques-Step-12.jpg?ajax=true&aid=53961" href="#/Image:Ease-Depression-with-Relaxation-Techniques-Step-12.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Ease Depression with Relaxation Techniques Step 12" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/0e/Ease-Depression-with-Relaxation-Techniques-Step-12.jpg/aid53961-v4-728px-Ease-Depression-with-Relaxation-Techniques-Step-12.jpg" height="546" id="img_fdfd4fedf2" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_fdfd4fedf2')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Ease Depression with Relaxation Techniques Step 12" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/0e/Ease-Depression-with-Relaxation-Techniques-Step-12.jpg/aid53961-v4-728px-Ease-Depression-with-Relaxation-Techniques-Step-12.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 1" class="step_num">1</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_3_1"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Try to get seven to nine hours of sleep each night.</b> <a href="/Sleep-Better-when-You-Have-Depression" title="Sleep Better when You Have Depression">Depression and difficulty sleeping</a> often go hand in hand.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 14" class="reference" id="_ref-14"><a href="#_note-14">[14]</a></sup> If you have trouble getting the recommended amount of sleep, try to work on developing healthy sleeping habits:<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 15" class="reference" id="_ref-15"><a href="#_note-15">[15]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>Go to bed and wake up at the same time each day.</li>
<li>Expose yourself to bright light just after waking.</li>
<li>Avoid eating a heavy meal within two or three hours of bedtime.</li>
<li>Avoid caffeine and alcohol, especially in the evening.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Ease-Depression-with-Relaxation-Techniques-Step-13.jpg?ajax=true&aid=53961" href="#/Image:Ease-Depression-with-Relaxation-Techniques-Step-13.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Ease Depression with Relaxation Techniques Step 13" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/84/Ease-Depression-with-Relaxation-Techniques-Step-13.jpg/aid53961-v4-728px-Ease-Depression-with-Relaxation-Techniques-Step-13.jpg" height="546" id="img_1fb9f1d267" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_1fb9f1d267')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Ease Depression with Relaxation Techniques Step 13" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/84/Ease-Depression-with-Relaxation-Techniques-Step-13.jpg/aid53961-v4-728px-Ease-Depression-with-Relaxation-Techniques-Step-13.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 2" class="step_num">2</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_3_2"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Eat a balanced diet.</b> Foods that contain lots of sugar, fat, and salt can mess with your brain’s reward system, which can worsen depression. Do your best to limit <a href="/Avoid-Foods-That-Worsen-Depression-and-Anxiety" title="Avoid Foods That Worsen Depression and Anxiety">foods that can worsen depression</a>, and maintain a healthy, balanced diet.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 16" class="reference" id="_ref-16"><a href="#_note-16">[16]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>Make sure you eat the recommended daily servings of proteins, fruits and veggies, and grains. You can find your daily requirements, recipe suggestions, and other nutrition resources on MyPlate: <a class="external free" href="https://www.fns.usda.gov/tn/myplate" rel="nofollow">https://www.fns.usda.gov/tn/myplate</a>.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Ease-Depression-with-Relaxation-Techniques-Step-14.jpg?ajax=true&aid=53961" href="#/Image:Ease-Depression-with-Relaxation-Techniques-Step-14.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Ease Depression with Relaxation Techniques Step 14" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/8c/Ease-Depression-with-Relaxation-Techniques-Step-14.jpg/aid53961-v4-728px-Ease-Depression-with-Relaxation-Techniques-Step-14.jpg" height="546" id="img_477ee9868f" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_477ee9868f')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Ease Depression with Relaxation Techniques Step 14" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/8c/Ease-Depression-with-Relaxation-Techniques-Step-14.jpg/aid53961-v4-728px-Ease-Depression-with-Relaxation-Techniques-Step-14.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 3" class="step_num">3</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_3_3"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Avoid consuming alcohol, caffeine, and other drugs.</b> Like junk food, alcohol, caffeine, nicotine, and other drugs can mess up your reward system and worsen depression.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 17" class="reference" id="_ref-17"><a href="#_note-17">[17]</a></sup>  Do your best to reduce your consumption of any of these substances. If possible, try to quit.

<ul>
<li>Drugs and alcohol can also interact with prescription medications. It’s important to be honest with your doctor and discuss potential drug interactions with them.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Ease-Depression-with-Relaxation-Techniques-Step-15.jpg?ajax=true&aid=53961" href="#/Image:Ease-Depression-with-Relaxation-Techniques-Step-15.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Ease Depression with Relaxation Techniques Step 15" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f3/Ease-Depression-with-Relaxation-Techniques-Step-15.jpg/aid53961-v4-728px-Ease-Depression-with-Relaxation-Techniques-Step-15.jpg" height="546" id="img_cfa7efce49" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_cfa7efce49')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Ease Depression with Relaxation Techniques Step 15" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f3/Ease-Depression-with-Relaxation-Techniques-Step-15.jpg/aid53961-v4-728px-Ease-Depression-with-Relaxation-Techniques-Step-15.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 4" class="step_num">4</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_3_4"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Do something you enjoy every day.</b> Allowing yourself to experience a simple pleasure is a key part of self care. Make a mental list of things you love to do and schedule time every day for your me-time.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 18" class="reference" id="_ref-18"><a href="#_note-18">[18]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>Examples might include enjoying a good cup of coffee on the patio, getting a massage, taking a hot bath, painting or drawing, and snuggling up with a blanket and good book.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Ease-Depression-with-Relaxation-Techniques-Step-16.jpg?ajax=true&aid=53961" href="#/Image:Ease-Depression-with-Relaxation-Techniques-Step-16.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Ease Depression with Relaxation Techniques Step 16" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/fb/Ease-Depression-with-Relaxation-Techniques-Step-16.jpg/aid53961-v4-728px-Ease-Depression-with-Relaxation-Techniques-Step-16.jpg" height="546" id="img_ca2e77da31" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_ca2e77da31')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Ease Depression with Relaxation Techniques Step 16" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/fb/Ease-Depression-with-Relaxation-Techniques-Step-16.jpg/aid53961-v4-728px-Ease-Depression-with-Relaxation-Techniques-Step-16.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 5" class="step_num">5</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_3_5"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Don’t overbook yourself.</b> When you make too many commitments, you set yourself up to fail. Stress can lead to feeling overwhelmed and depressed, so try to avoid packing your schedule. Break big projects up into smaller tasks that you can complete over several days, and don’t be afraid to say no to commitments you can’t keep.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 19" class="reference" id="_ref-19"><a href="#_note-19">[19]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>Avoid procrastinating so things don’t pile up on you.</li>
<li>Remember to give yourself time for breaks. Never feel bad if you need time to restore and recharge.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Ease-Depression-with-Relaxation-Techniques-Step-17.jpg?ajax=true&aid=53961" href="#/Image:Ease-Depression-with-Relaxation-Techniques-Step-17.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Ease Depression with Relaxation Techniques Step 17" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/68/Ease-Depression-with-Relaxation-Techniques-Step-17.jpg/aid53961-v4-728px-Ease-Depression-with-Relaxation-Techniques-Step-17.jpg" height="546" id="img_0d8eae6043" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_0d8eae6043')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Ease Depression with Relaxation Techniques Step 17" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/68/Ease-Depression-with-Relaxation-Techniques-Step-17.jpg/aid53961-v4-728px-Ease-Depression-with-Relaxation-Techniques-Step-17.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 6" class="step_num">6</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_3_6"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Try <a href="/Start-a-Journal" title="Start a Journal">keeping a journal</a>.</b> Journaling can help you release tension, put order to chaotic feelings, track your progress over time, and find motivation to handle future struggles. Set aside 15 or 20 minutes to jot down that day’s events, your feelings, conflicts, and worries. Every two or three weeks, read back your entries to remind yourself how you’ve overcome problems.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 20" class="reference" id="_ref-20"><a href="#_note-20">[20]</a></sup>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage final_li">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Ease-Depression-with-Relaxation-Techniques-Step-18.jpg?ajax=true&aid=53961" href="#/Image:Ease-Depression-with-Relaxation-Techniques-Step-18.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Ease Depression with Relaxation Techniques Step 18" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/61/Ease-Depression-with-Relaxation-Techniques-Step-18.jpg/aid53961-v4-728px-Ease-Depression-with-Relaxation-Techniques-Step-18.jpg" height="546" id="img_e0b9aa3503" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_e0b9aa3503')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Ease Depression with Relaxation Techniques Step 18" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/61/Ease-Depression-with-Relaxation-Techniques-Step-18.jpg/aid53961-v4-728px-Ease-Depression-with-Relaxation-Techniques-Step-18.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 7" class="step_num">7</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_3_7"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Do your best to stay social.</b> Depression often leads to isolation, which in turn feeds depression and creates a vicious cycle. When you feel like isolating yourself, do your best to motivate yourself to reach out to someone. Give a friend or family member a call and ask them if they can hang out or have a chat.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 21" class="reference" id="_ref-21"><a href="#_note-21">[21]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>Other ways to stay social might be a local support group, religious services, or a group hobby or exercise class.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
</ol>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</div>
</div>
<a class="anchor" name="Questions_and_Answers_sub"></a>
<div class="qa section sticky qa_show_unanswered_questions" data-aid="53961" data-few_contribs="1" data-search_enabled="0">
<h2>
<div class="altblock"></div>
<span class="mw-headline" id="qa_headline">Community Q&A</span>
</h2>
<div class="section_text" id="qa">
<div id="qa_answered_questions_container">
<div id="qa_aq_search_container">
<div class="qa_section_heading" id="qa_aq_search_heading">Search</div>
<input class="qa_aq_search" placeholder="Type your query here"/>
</div>
<a id="qa_add_curated_question">Add New Question</a>
<ul class="qa_questions qa_aqs" id="qa_article_questions">
<li class="qa_aq qa_block" data-aqid="331455" data-caid="332328" data-cqid="331472" data-qa_inactive="0" data-sqid="1916853" data-submitter_id="0" data-verifier_id="0" data-votes_down="0" data-votes_up="2">
<div class="qa_divider"></div>
<div class="qa_li_container">
<div class="qa_question_tab">Question</div>
<div class="qa_q_txt question">What is heartfulness? Is it different from mindfulness?</div>
<div class="qa_answers">
<div class="qa_user_area">
<div class="qa_user_hover hint_box"></div>
<div class="qa_badge"></div>
<div class="qa_person_circle"></div>
<div class="qa_answerer_info">
<div class="qa_user_name"></div>
<div class="qa_user_label">Community Answer</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="qa_answer answer">I think you're asking the difference between mindfulness meditation and loving-kindness meditation? If not, sorry. Mindfulness is about being aware of you, your body, and your thoughts, and trying to clear them and be present. Loving-kindness meditation is meditating on sending out good feelings towards others, usually progressively to larger and larger groups.</div>
<div class="qa_answer_footer">
<div class="wh_vote_container qa_vote_buttons">
<span class="wh_thumb_response wh_thumb_msg">Thanks!</span>
<div class="qa_widget_vote_links">
<a class="wh_vote_up wh_vote_box button secondary" href="#">Yes</a>
<a class="wh_vote_down wh_vote_box button secondary" href="#">No</a>
</div>
<div class="qa_widget_vote_buttons">
<a class="wh_vote_down wh_vote_box" href="#">Not Helpful <span>0</span></a>
<a class="wh_vote_up wh_vote_box" href="#">Helpful <span>2</span></a>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</li>
<li class="qa_aq qa_block" data-aqid="203283" data-caid="204156" data-cqid="203300" data-qa_inactive="0" data-sqid="1274859" data-submitter_id="4088798" data-verifier_id="0" data-votes_down="2" data-votes_up="5">
<div class="qa_divider"></div>
<div class="qa_li_container">
<div class="qa_question_tab">Question</div>
<div class="qa_q_txt question">At which point does a depressed person give up and how long will it last?</div>
<div class="qa_answers">
<div class="qa_ta_area">
<div class="qa_user_hover hint_box"></div>
<div class="qa_badge"></div>
<div class="qa_person_circle" style="background-image:url(https://www.wikihow.com/images/avatarOut/5/55/4088798.jpg?20170215114325)"></div>
<div class="qa_answerer_info">
<div class="qa_user_name"><span class="qa_user_link" data-href="/User:Irdanwen">Tom De Backer</span></div>
<div class="qa_user_label">Top Answerer</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="qa_answer answer">Everyone has a different breaking point. For some, giving up is the only way to overcome a depression, because it helps them to accept the fact that they are depressed, which is one of the first steps in treating it. Others may be so daunted by the idea of giving up, that it motivates them towards healing a depression. Ask for help, take your time, remember that it is very normal to be depressed. </div>
<div class="qa_answer_footer">
<div class="wh_vote_container qa_vote_buttons">
<span class="wh_thumb_response wh_thumb_msg">Thanks!</span>
<div class="qa_widget_vote_links">
<a class="wh_vote_up wh_vote_box button secondary" href="#">Yes</a>
<a class="wh_vote_down wh_vote_box button secondary" href="#">No</a>
</div>
<div class="qa_widget_vote_buttons">
<a class="wh_vote_down wh_vote_box" href="#">Not Helpful <span>2</span></a>
<a class="wh_vote_up wh_vote_box" href="#">Helpful <span>5</span></a>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</li>
</ul>
</div>

<div class="section quicksummary sticky summary_with_video" id="quick_summary_section">
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Quick_Summary">wikiHow Video: How to Ease Depression with Relaxation Techniques</span></h2>
<div class="section_text" id="quicksummary">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatright summarysection" style="max-width:728px"><div class="content-spacer" style="padding-top: 56.25%;"><div class="video-player"><a href="/Video/Ease-Depression-with-Relaxation-Techniques" id="summary_video_link"><img class="m-video content-fill placeholder" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/7e/Ease-Depression-with-Relaxation-Techniques-Step-0-Version-2.jpg/1000px-nowatermark-Ease-Depression-with-Relaxation-Techniques-Step-0-Version-2.jpg" id="summary_video_poster"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('summary_video_poster')</script><div class="m-video-intro-over" style="visibility:visible"><div class="m-video-play">
<div class="m-video-play-count-triangle"></div> <span class="m-video-play-text">Watch</span>
</div></div></a>
</div></div></div>
<script type="text/javascript">
//<![CDATA[
if (WH.video)WH.video.add(document.getElementById('mvid-a58d8a98e2'));
//]]>
</script>
</div>
<div id="summary_wrapper"><div id="summary_text">
<h2>Article Summary<a href="#" id="summary_close">X</a>
</h2>
<p>The best way to ease depression with relaxation techniques is to meditate. Meditate for thirty minutes a day in a quiet place. Search for guided-meditation videos online if you need help. Practice controlling your breathing by inhaling for five seconds and then exhaling slowly. It may be hard at first, but you'll get there! <span id="summary_last_sentence">Keep reading to learn how other techniques, like exercise and yoga, can help with your depression!</span><span class="sumpos_bottom" id="summary_position"></span></p>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Warnings">Warnings</span></h2>
<div class="section_text" id="warnings">
<ul>
<li>If you are thinking about hurting yourself or others, call the US suicide hotline at 1-800-273-TALK.</li>
<li>If you have symptoms of clinical depression for more than two weeks, contact your doctor about other steps you can take.</li>
</ul>

<div class="section" id="article_info_section">
<h2 class="section_head" id="article_info_header"><span>Article Info</span></h2>

<p class="info author_info">This article was co-authored by <a href="/Special:ArticleReviewers?name=tasharube%2Clmsw#tasharube%2Clmsw">Tasha Rube, LMSW</a>. Tasha Rube is a Licensed Master Social Worker in Missouri. She received her MSW from the University of Missouri in 2014.</p>

    "@context": "http:\/\/schema.org",
    "@type": "HowTo",

    "mainEntityOfPage": {
        "@type": "WebPage",

    },
    "image": {
        "@type": "ImageObject",
        "url": "https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/6\/61\/Ease-Depression-with-Relaxation-Techniques-Step-18.jpg\/aid53961-v4-1200px-Ease-Depression-with-Relaxation-Techniques-Step-18.jpg",
        "width": 1200,
        "height": 900
    },
    "author": {
        "@context": "http:\/\/schema.org",
        "@type": "Organization",
        "name": "wikiHow",
        "url": "https:\/\/www.wikihow.com",
        "logo": {
            "@type": "ImageObject",

    "aggregateRating": {
        "@type": "AggregateRating",

    "datePublished": "2006-08-08",

    "publisher": {

        "url": "https:\/\/www.wikihow.com",
        "logo": {
            "@type": "ImageObject",
            "url": "https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/skins\/owl\/images\/wikihow_logo_name_green_60.png",
            "width": 326,
            "height": 60
        },
        "sameAs": [
            "https:\/\/www.facebook.com\/wikiHow\/",
            "https:\/\/twitter.com\/wikiHow",

    "contributor": {
        "@type": "Person",

    },
    "step": [
        {
            "@type": "HowToSection",
            "name": "Calming Your Mind",
            "position": 1,
            "itemListElement": [
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 1,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Try controlled breathing exercises. Get into a comfortable position, then breathe in deeply through your nose and fill your belly with air. Count slowly to five as you breathe in, then gently exhale through your mouth as you count to five again. [2]\nDo your breathing exercises for three to five minutes whenever you feel overwhelmed or experience other symptoms.\nInstead of counting as you breathe, you can also think or say a soothing word, like \"relax.\"[3]"
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 2,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Meditate for 20 to 30 minutes a day. Wear loose, comfortable clothes, and set aside some time when you\u2019ll be free of distractions. Sit upright with your chest out and shoulders back. Keep your feet flat on the floor if you\u2019re sitting in a chair, or cross your legs if you\u2019re on the floor. Close your eyes, breathe deeply, and envision your breath flowing in and out of you.[4]\nFocus completely on your breath as you inhale through your nose and exhale through your mouth. Imagine each breath fills you with light, and draws wandering, chaotic thoughts to a single point.\nIf you notice your attention wandering from your breath, just refocus again. Don\u2019t judge or criticize yourself, simply return your attention to your breath.\nYou can also look for guided meditations on YouTube and other services."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 3,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Practice positive self talk. When a negative thought comes to mind, acknowledge it instead of trying to push it aside. Say it out loud or write it down, then say, \u201cThis is a negative, exaggerated thought.\u201d Challenge it with a realistic thought to take away its power.[5]\nFor example, if you starting thinking to yourself, \u201cI\u2019m worthless,\u201d acknowledge the thought and say, \u201cNo - that\u2019s an exaggerated, black and white thought. My family needs me, my friends treasure me, and my boss values my work.\u201d\nDo your best to take the power away from negative thoughts before they start to spiral. Try not to see things as black and white or absolute and unchangeable."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 4,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Celebrate every small success. Throughout the day, stop to acknowledge small victories. Depression can make it tough just to get out of bed, so even something seemingly minor like getting dressed could be something to celebrate.[6]\nTry starting your day by making the bed. It might seem trivial, but it\u2019s a way to start off each day with an accomplishment.\nPraise yourself for things like cleaning, going outside, cooking a healthy meal, and exercising."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 5,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Visualize calming situations. Sit somewhere comfortable without distractions, close your eyes, and breathe slowly. Calm your mind by focusing on peaceful images. Think of a place that you find relaxing, like a childhood refuge, a mountain retreat, or an exotic beach location.[7]\nOpen your imagination to the sensations that you would feel in this place: the sounds, smells, colors, textures, and temperature. Visualize the place with as many sensory details as you can. Spend 10 to 15 minutes in this restful place before opening your eyes.\nVisualization can help you relax, minimize stress, and improve the quality of your sleep."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 6,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Visualize solutions to your conflict. You can also visualize positive resolutions if a specific conflict prompted your symptoms. Identify your conflict and bring its image to mind. If you stand before it and feel very small, inhale deeply, and imagine yourself growing taller and taller. Imagine that from this new height you have the power to see new ways to solve the problem.[8]\nFor example, if you\u2019re feeling powerless, overwhelmed, and hopeless because of a fight with your significant other, envision yourself becoming larger than the conflict. Say to yourself, \u201cI have the power to resolve this conflict.\u201d Then, try to break down the situation into its facts, and visualize a conversation with your partner that could resolve the conflict."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 7,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Listen to calming music. Listening to music can ease stress, depression, and anxiety. Play your favorite soothing tracks when you\u2019re at home, going for a walk, or driving your car. Instead of watching television, try turning on the stereo.[9]\nThe type of music that relaxes you will depend on your personal preference.\nSinging can also be a great way to relax or release tension."
                    }
                }
            ]
        },
        {
            "@type": "HowToSection",
            "name": "Trying Physical Techniques",
            "position": 2,
            "itemListElement": [
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 1,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Stretch your muscles to raise your spirits. Take 10 to 15 minutes to stretch when you wake up and before you go to bed. Develop a routine and stretch your legs, back, and arms. Stretching regularly can energize your body, increase blood flow to your muscles, and help relieve symptoms of anxiety and depression.[10]\nSince it might be hard to get motivated enough to exercise, stretching can be a good way to get moving if you\u2019re depressed."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 2,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Try progressive muscle relaxation. Set aside about 15 minutes of time free of distractions. Find a comfortable place to sit, close your eyes, and take several slow, deep breaths. Inhale and tense one muscle group, such as your toes, then hold the tension for about five seconds.[11]\nLet the tension go and relax the muscles as you exhale slowly. Notice the muscles go limp as the tension disappears. Repeat the process and work through the muscles in your legs, torso, arms, shoulders, neck, and head. \u00a0"
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 3,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Try to get daily aerobic exercise. From walking the dog to taking judo classes, aerobic exercise isn\u2019t just good for your heart. It can reduce stress hormones and stimulate mood-elevating chemicals in your brain. Focusing on movement while you exercise also allows you to take a break from depression and any conflicts surrounding it.[12]\nHaving an exercise buddy can help keep you accountable on those days when you just want to stay in bed. Try to enlist a friend to help!"
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 4,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Start doing yoga. Yoga involves meditation, physical exercise, and controlled breathing, so it can help ease both your mind and body. If you\u2019re a beginner, look for classes at your local YMCA or yoga studio. You can also search for yoga videos on YouTube and health and fitness websites.[13]"
                    }
                }
            ]
        },
        {
            "@type": "HowToSection",
            "name": "Taking Care of Yourself",
            "position": 3,
            "itemListElement": [
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 1,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Try to get seven to nine hours of sleep each night. Depression and difficulty sleeping often go hand in hand.[14] If you have trouble getting the recommended amount of sleep, try to work on developing healthy sleeping habits:[15]\nGo to bed and wake up at the same time each day.\nExpose yourself to bright light just after waking.\nAvoid eating a heavy meal within two or three hours of bedtime.\nAvoid caffeine and alcohol, especially in the evening."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 2,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Eat a balanced diet. Foods that contain lots of sugar, fat, and salt can mess with your brain\u2019s reward system, which can worsen depression. Do your best to limit foods that can worsen depression, and maintain a healthy, balanced diet.[16]\nMake sure you eat the recommended daily servings of proteins, fruits and veggies, and grains. You can find your daily requirements, recipe suggestions, and other nutrition resources on MyPlate: https:\/\/www.fns.usda.gov\/tn\/myplate."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 3,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Avoid consuming alcohol, caffeine, and other drugs. Like junk food, alcohol, caffeine, nicotine, and other drugs can mess up your reward system and worsen depression.[17] \u00a0Do your best to reduce your consumption of any of these substances. If possible, try to quit.\n\nDrugs and alcohol can also interact with prescription medications. It\u2019s important to be honest with your doctor and discuss potential drug interactions with them."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 4,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Do something you enjoy every day. Allowing yourself to experience a simple pleasure is a key part of self care. Make a mental list of things you love to do and schedule time every day for your me-time.[18]\nExamples might include enjoying a good cup of coffee on the patio, getting a massage, taking a hot bath, painting or drawing, and snuggling up with a blanket and good book."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 5,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Don\u2019t overbook yourself. When you make too many commitments, you set yourself up to fail. Stress can lead to feeling overwhelmed and depressed, so try to avoid packing your schedule. Break big projects up into smaller tasks that you can complete over several days, and don\u2019t be afraid to say no to commitments you can\u2019t keep.[19]\nAvoid procrastinating so things don\u2019t pile up on you.\nRemember to give yourself time for breaks. Never feel bad if you need time to restore and recharge."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 6,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Try keeping a journal. Journaling can help you release tension, put order to chaotic feelings, track your progress over time, and find motivation to handle future struggles. Set aside 15 or 20 minutes to jot down that day\u2019s events, your feelings, conflicts, and worries. Every two or three weeks, read back your entries to remind yourself how you\u2019ve overcome problems.[20]"
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 7,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Do your best to stay social. Depression often leads to isolation, which in turn feeds depression and creates a vicious cycle. When you feel like isolating yourself, do your best to motivate yourself to reach out to someone. Give a friend or family member a call and ask them if they can hang out or have a chat.[21]\nOther ways to stay social might be a local support group, religious services, or a group hobby or exercise class."
                    }
                }
            ]
        }
    ],
    "description": "How to Ease Depression with Relaxation Techniques. Living with depression can be an immense struggle. If you're feeling overwhelmed, anxious, or hopeless, relaxation techniques could help you find some relief.http:\/\/www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov\/..."

title: How to Ease Depression with Relaxation Techniques
content_html:
Try controlled breathing exercises. Get into a comfortable position, then breathe in deeply through your nose and fill your belly with air. Count slowly to five as you breathe in, then gently exhale through your mouth as you count to five again. [2]
  • Do your breathing exercises for three to five minutes whenever you feel overwhelmed or experience other symptoms.
  • Instead of counting as you breathe, you can also think or say a soothing word, like "relax."[3]
Meditate for 20 to 30 minutes a day. Wear loose, comfortable clothes, and set aside some time when you’ll be free of distractions. Sit upright with your chest out and shoulders back. Keep your feet flat on the floor if you’re sitting in a chair, or cross your legs if you’re on the floor. Close your eyes, breathe deeply, and envision your breath flowing in and out of you.[4]
  • Focus completely on your breath as you inhale through your nose and exhale through your mouth. Imagine each breath fills you with light, and draws wandering, chaotic thoughts to a single point.
  • If you notice your attention wandering from your breath, just refocus again. Don’t judge or criticize yourself, simply return your attention to your breath.
  • You can also look for guided meditations on YouTube and other services.
Practice positive self talk. When a negative thought comes to mind, acknowledge it instead of trying to push it aside. Say it out loud or write it down, then say, “This is a negative, exaggerated thought.” Challenge it with a realistic thought to take away its power.[5]
  • For example, if you starting thinking to yourself, “I’m worthless,” acknowledge the thought and say, “No - that’s an exaggerated, black and white thought. My family needs me, my friends treasure me, and my boss values my work.”
  • Do your best to take the power away from negative thoughts before they start to spiral. Try not to see things as black and white or absolute and unchangeable.
Celebrate every small success. Throughout the day, stop to acknowledge small victories. Depression can make it tough just to get out of bed, so even something seemingly minor like getting dressed could be something to celebrate.[6]
  • Try starting your day by making the bed. It might seem trivial, but it’s a way to start off each day with an accomplishment.
  • Praise yourself for things like cleaning, going outside, cooking a healthy meal, and exercising.
Visualize calming situations. Sit somewhere comfortable without distractions, close your eyes, and breathe slowly. Calm your mind by focusing on peaceful images. Think of a place that you find relaxing, like a childhood refuge, a mountain retreat, or an exotic beach location.[7]
  • Open your imagination to the sensations that you would feel in this place: the sounds, smells, colors, textures, and temperature. Visualize the place with as many sensory details as you can. Spend 10 to 15 minutes in this restful place before opening your eyes.
  • Visualization can help you relax, minimize stress, and improve the quality of your sleep.
Visualize solutions to your conflict. You can also visualize positive resolutions if a specific conflict prompted your symptoms. Identify your conflict and bring its image to mind. If you stand before it and feel very small, inhale deeply, and imagine yourself growing taller and taller. Imagine that from this new height you have the power to see new ways to solve the problem.[8]
  • For example, if you’re feeling powerless, overwhelmed, and hopeless because of a fight with your significant other, envision yourself becoming larger than the conflict. Say to yourself, “I have the power to resolve this conflict.” Then, try to break down the situation into its facts, and visualize a conversation with your partner that could resolve the conflict.
Listen to calming music. Listening to music can ease stress, depression, and anxiety. Play your favorite soothing tracks when you’re at home, going for a walk, or driving your car. Instead of watching television, try turning on the stereo.[9]
  • The type of music that relaxes you will depend on your personal preference.
  • Singing can also be a great way to relax or release tension.
Stretch your muscles to raise your spirits. Take 10 to 15 minutes to stretch when you wake up and before you go to bed. Develop a routine and stretch your legs, back, and arms. Stretching regularly can energize your body, increase blood flow to your muscles, and help relieve symptoms of anxiety and depression.[10]
  • Since it might be hard to get motivated enough to exercise, stretching can be a good way to get moving if you’re depressed.
Try progressive muscle relaxation. Set aside about 15 minutes of time free of distractions. Find a comfortable place to sit, close your eyes, and take several slow, deep breaths. Inhale and tense one muscle group, such as your toes, then hold the tension for about five seconds.[11]
  • Let the tension go and relax the muscles as you exhale slowly. Notice the muscles go limp as the tension disappears. Repeat the process and work through the muscles in your legs, torso, arms, shoulders, neck, and head.  
Try to get daily aerobic exercise. From walking the dog to taking judo classes, aerobic exercise isn’t just good for your heart. It can reduce stress hormones and stimulate mood-elevating chemicals in your brain. Focusing on movement while you exercise also allows you to take a break from depression and any conflicts surrounding it.[12]
  • Having an exercise buddy can help keep you accountable on those days when you just want to stay in bed. Try to enlist a friend to help!
Start doing yoga. Yoga involves meditation, physical exercise, and controlled breathing, so it can help ease both your mind and body. If you’re a beginner, look for classes at your local YMCA or yoga studio. You can also search for yoga videos on YouTube and health and fitness websites.[13]
Try to get seven to nine hours of sleep each night. Depression and difficulty sleeping often go hand in hand.[14] If you have trouble getting the recommended amount of sleep, try to work on developing healthy sleeping habits:[15]
  • Go to bed and wake up at the same time each day.
  • Expose yourself to bright light just after waking.
  • Avoid eating a heavy meal within two or three hours of bedtime.
  • Avoid caffeine and alcohol, especially in the evening.
Eat a balanced diet. Foods that contain lots of sugar, fat, and salt can mess with your brain’s reward system, which can worsen depression. Do your best to limit foods that can worsen depression, and maintain a healthy, balanced diet.[16]
  • Make sure you eat the recommended daily servings of proteins, fruits and veggies, and grains. You can find your daily requirements, recipe suggestions, and other nutrition resources on MyPlate: https://www.fns.usda.gov/tn/myplate.
Avoid consuming alcohol, caffeine, and other drugs. Like junk food, alcohol, caffeine, nicotine, and other drugs can mess up your reward system and worsen depression.[17]  Do your best to reduce your consumption of any of these substances. If possible, try to quit.
  • Drugs and alcohol can also interact with prescription medications. It’s important to be honest with your doctor and discuss potential drug interactions with them.
Do something you enjoy every day. Allowing yourself to experience a simple pleasure is a key part of self care. Make a mental list of things you love to do and schedule time every day for your me-time.[18]
  • Examples might include enjoying a good cup of coffee on the patio, getting a massage, taking a hot bath, painting or drawing, and snuggling up with a blanket and good book.
Don’t overbook yourself. When you make too many commitments, you set yourself up to fail. Stress can lead to feeling overwhelmed and depressed, so try to avoid packing your schedule. Break big projects up into smaller tasks that you can complete over several days, and don’t be afraid to say no to commitments you can’t keep.[19]
  • Avoid procrastinating so things don’t pile up on you.
  • Remember to give yourself time for breaks. Never feel bad if you need time to restore and recharge.
Try keeping a journal. Journaling can help you release tension, put order to chaotic feelings, track your progress over time, and find motivation to handle future struggles. Set aside 15 or 20 minutes to jot down that day’s events, your feelings, conflicts, and worries. Every two or three weeks, read back your entries to remind yourself how you’ve overcome problems.[20]
Do your best to stay social. Depression often leads to isolation, which in turn feeds depression and creates a vicious cycle. When you feel like isolating yourself, do your best to motivate yourself to reach out to someone. Give a friend or family member a call and ask them if they can hang out or have a chat.[21]
  • Other ways to stay social might be a local support group, religious services, or a group hobby or exercise class.
